title: Maximum Conductive Hearing Loss Secondary to Surgical Closure of the External Auditory Canal
chief_complaint: I am having significant difficulty hearing and bothersome ringing in my left ear. I also have pain behind my left ear, a feeling of fullness in my left ear, and intermittent headaches. The pain and headaches started about 3 months ago.

problem_summary.onset: Pain and headaches began 3 months prior to the appointment; hearing loss is chronic following past surgeries.
problem_summary.course: Stable hearing loss; recent onset of pain and headaches.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (left), aural fullness (left), mastoid pain (left), headaches.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation for pain and hearing issues after referral from otolaryngology.

history.present_illness: Patient reports pain in the left mastoid region and headaches starting 3 months ago. Also reports significant hearing handicap and tinnitus in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: History of recurrent cholesteatoma in the left ear. Underwent two surgeries in Colombia. The left external auditory canal was surgically closed during the second procedure (blind sac closure). Surgical records were not available.
history.medical_psych_history: Fibromyalgia, meningoencephalocele, and a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago.
history.prior_management: Referred to neurotologist due to complex history, then to audiology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal hearing thresholds with slight elevation at 500 Hz for bone conduction. Left ear: Severe rising to moderately severe conductive hearing loss with significant air-bone gaps (45-65 dB) at 250-4000 Hz. Bone conduction thresholds are within normal limits bilaterally. Interaural asymmetry of 45-65 dB HL for air conduction thresholds, with the left ear being poorer than the right ear.

numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: 55-70 dB HL (severe rising to moderately severe)
numeric_results.Bone_Conduction_Right: Within normal limits; slight loss at 500 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal speech reception and recognition in the right ear. Elevated SRT in the left ear consistent with conductive loss, but excellent word recognition (100%) when presented at sufficient volume.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function in the right ear. Left ear could not be tested due to canal closure.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflex Thresholds
tests.key_findings: Could not evaluate immittance on the left ear due to surgical closure of the ear canal. Right ear acoustic reflex testing performed.

tests.name: Distortion Product Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAEs)
tests.key_findings: Present and robust at 1,600 to 8,000 Hz in the right ear. Could not be performed in the left ear.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a maximum conductive hearing loss in the left ear. The left ear demonstrates a severe rising to moderately severe air-conduction loss, but bone conduction thresholds remain within normal limits, indicating intact cochlear function. Speech recognition scores are excellent (100%) bilaterally when the signal is loud enough to overcome the conductive component.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms that your inner ear (nerve) function is normal on both sides.
The hearing loss in your left ear is 'conductive,' meaning sound cannot travel through the ear canal to the inner ear because the canal was surgically closed.
Because the nerve is healthy, you have excellent potential to understand speech if sound can bypass the closed canal (e.g., via bone conduction).
We cannot perform standard pressure tests or look inside the left ear due to the surgical closure.
A Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) or CROS hearing aid would be good options to improve your hearing from the left side.
Your report of pain and headaches requires medical attention from the neurotologist.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient with a complex medical history who is concerned about new pain in an ear that has been 'stable' since surgery years ago.
You are aware your left ear canal is closed and do not expect standard ear probes to be used on that side.
You have difficulty localizing sound and hearing in background noise due to the single-sided deafness effect caused by the conductive block.
Express concern about the new symptoms (pain, headaches) - these are different from your chronic hearing issues.
You had the surgeries in Colombia and do not have access to the surgical records.
